WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 321 March 1979 FRUIT AND VEGETABLE EXPORTS FROM THE MEDITERRANEAN AREA TO THE EEC The paper reviews trade patterns and volumes of the major fruit and vegetable exporters among developing Mediterranean countries and the major EEC importing countries, with due consideration of seasonality of production. By setting the array of EEC import market regulations against the seasonality of the EEC diomestic production and the EEC's Common Agricultural Policy, some implications for future trade prospects are developed. Finally, with this background, projections through 1985 of domestic supply and demand for 36 different fruits and vegetables are made, and from these trade and interna- tional prices are then projected. Prepared by R.D. Hunt Europe, Middle East and North Africa Projects Department Copyright QJ1979 The World Bank 1818 H Street, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20433 U.S.A.

 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS i. Selection of the countries and commodities for detailed scrutiny was based on the significance of their contribution to trade in fruit and vegetables between the EEC and the Bank's European, Middle East, and North African (EMENA) Region developing countries. The EEC is the largest regional importer of fresh fruit and vegetables among non-centrally planned economies, with Germany, France and the UK as the largest single country importers of the EEC countries. EEC consumption patterns are generally quite stable, vary- ing only with supply and price, as income elasticities are low. Restricted entry for imports and the internal support price system moderate such supply and price fluctuations. Although the EEC is largely self-sufficient in production of fresh fruit and vegetables on an annual basis, climatic factors restrict the range and timing of EEC production. Market access regulations reflect this, permitting entry of substantial imports in EEC off-production seasons. Proximity and suitable production conditions continue to maintain the EMENA developing countries around the Mediterranean as major exporters of fruits and vegetables to the EEC. The seven countries concerned, referred to hereafter as EMENA-7, are Cyprus, Egypt, Greece, Israel, Morocco, Spain and Turkey. These were selected on the basis of their major contribution to the total fruit and vegetable trade between the EEC and the EMENA Region. ii. Growth in EEC fruit imports has been small in terms of volume at about 4% annually, but growth in terms of value has been substantial, about 22% annually, which compares with about 18% per annum for total world imports. Due to the annual nature of production, and the substantial fluctuations and slow growth in trade, it is difficult to make any meaningful statement about growth in trade in vegetables in general. However, growth in total world and EEC imports in value terms has been about 22% per annum, but in volume terms it has been negligible. The decline in export supplies of major staple items, such as potatoes and onions from Egypt, is a factor in the low rate of EEC growth, as also is the decline in intra-EEC trade in most vegetables. But imports of a large number of lesser-volume perishable vegetables have shown rapid growth. Growth in EMENA-7 exports of both fruit and vegetables has been about the 'same as that of EEC imports in value terms, while in volume terms it has far exceeded EEC import growth. The distribution of market shares of EEC fruit imports has remained constant, as might be expected in the short to medium term due to the long gestation period for fruit production. But shares of vegetable imports have shifted away from the rest of world in favor of the EEC itself and to a lesser extent in favor of EMENA-7. This is due to the introduction of protective measures under the EEC's Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) and the relatively easier access afforded to EMENA-7 as compared with the rest of the world. iii. The CAP is an elaborate price-regulating and tariff-setting mechanism which supports and protects the EEC agricultural sector. Domestic producer prices are supported at levels originally based on costs of production but now politically determined. Imports are regulated by tariffs and a reference (minimum entry) price and a variable import levy system to ensure supplies con- sonant with maintenance of domestic prices. The CAP is not yet fully opera- tional for all fruits and vegetables due to its administrative cumbersomeness,
 - ii - which is exacerbated by the highly fluctuating nature of supply and prices for these commodities. But most fruits and vegetables of significance in domestic EEC production are now covered, and the aim is to incorporate the remainder into the system in the near future. The CAP has been successful in limiting access to the EEC market, but it has not abated the severe price instability that is traditional of the fresh fruit and vegetable market. Thus, skilled market management continues to be necessary for a successful export operation to the EEC. iv. The EEC modifies its restricted market access somewhat through trade agreements with individual EMENA-7 and other countries and with groups of developing countries. These agreements confer varying reductions in t:he ad valorem tariffs and limit import quotas that are free of the variable levy system; the quotas can be totally suspended, as can all imports, by unilateral action in times of over-supply, thereby shifting the immediate burden ,of adjustment to the exporter. This effect is now worsening over time as the politically determined high producer prices move the EEC to greater leve:Ls of self-sufficiency for most products and even to a net exporter status for an increasing number of them. The latter trend has given rise to the need for domestic consumer and export subsidies in the EEC as a means of disposing of the surplus. v. Bilateral treaties with Mediterranean area countries are now being negotiated within a broader policy of equalizing competitive conditions between exporting countries in the area and of de-emphasizing of the previous basis of historical relationships. However, equalization of competition is lilkely to be negated if the EEC membership is broadened to include countries such as Greece and Spain. Developed Southern Hemisphere countries such as Australia, New Zealand and South Africa have major shares of the EEC import market, particularly in tree fruits, and their increasing production and market- ing efficiencies enable them to expand these. Low-cost production, improved transportation, and increasing concessionary treatment are also giving rise to competition from African, Caribbean, and Pacific (ACP) developing countries in a growing number of commodities, particularly where the reference-price/ variable-levy system is not yet in effect. This will require a response in terms of improved efficiency by EMENA exporters in order to retain their market share. vi. EEC imports show a distinct seasonality, based on market access regulations designed to protect the domestic producer. Imports peak durLng the EEC off-production season with the exception of some commodities, such as oranges where self-sufficiency is low and seasonality of production is the same in the EEC and the EMENA exporting countries. The optimum import period, when import prices are highest, occurs during the EEC off-production season, which is when EMENA-7 exports peak. This indicates that EMENA exporters have generally adapted their supplies to seasonal fluctuations in demand, and the scope for further adaptation of this kind is at best marginal. Monthly price indices indicate, as expected, that seasonal price movements among the EEC-5 1/ countries are very similar, although prices do peak in 1/ Belgium-Luxembourg, France, Germany, Italy, and the United Kingdom.
 different months for different countries. The seasonal price indices are also of use in decomposing the study's projected annual average prices into monthly components for project analysis where export timing is known. vii. The price projections through 1985 for the 36 commodities bear out the general impression of the indifferent EEC import market outlook in view of the widespread competition and restricted access. In constant terms, signif- icant price increases (greater than 1% p.a.) are projected only for 6 commodi- ties, 1/ all of relatively low unit value. While EMENA-7 countries do pre- sently have the major import market share (68%), their exports of all but one item (peaches) are expected to decline, consequently they will benefit less than might be expected in the absence of an additional production and export effort. Such effort could be worthwhile in view of the expanding EEC demand and the relatively great price elasticity of demand for the commodities. For most commodities, very small price movements (less than 1% p.a.) in constant terms are foreseen. However, those with positive movements 2/ are the ones of higher unit value, and the EMENA-7 countries do have 50% of the import market. EEC import demand is expected to increase for each commodity, as are EMENA-7 exports, except for cherries and lettuce, but at a much lower rate than EEC imports. Additional production for export is also worthwhile for cherries and lettuce. Minor price declines in constant terms are foreseen for 9 commodities; 3/ these are of medium-level unit value and are of less- than-average importance to EMENA-7 exporters. Any expansion here should be cautious, very selective, and based on concrete knowledge of superior market- ing arrangements. Significant price declines, in constant terms, are forecast for a large number of commodities. 4/ The EMENA-7 countries' import market share of the commodities showing large price declines averages 45%, and their exports of all such commodities are projected to increase at a more rapid rate than import demand. Further export effort here should be discouraged. 1/ Melons, peaches, onions, potatoes, lentils and dry peas. 2/ Cherries, lemons, oranges, strawberries, lettuce and fresh beans. 3/ Pears, plums, artichokes, cauliflowers, celery, eggplants, garlic, tomatoes and fresh peas. 4/ Apples, apricots, avocados, grapefruit, mandarins, tangerines, asparagus, carrots, cucumbers, green peppers, broad beans and dry beans.
 - iv - INTRODUCTION Continued identification of additional productive capacity for fruit and vegetables in the Europe, Middle East and North Africa (EMENA) Region LDCs, particularly those bordering the Mediterranean, has led to increasing numbers of export-oriented fruit and vegetable projects on the general assumption of availability of export market outlets in the EEC0 Periodic surpluses and increased trade protection measures in the EEC has led to serious questioning of the validity of the assumption of continued export market availability. This study reviews the state of fruit and vegetable trade between the EEC, represented by its 5 major importing countries 1/ and the EMENA LDCs, repre- sented by 7 major exporting countries, 2/ in terms of structure, trade poli- cies and seasonality and makes quantitative projections of the future outlook for this trade. The large number of countries involved (16), 3/ the large number of diverse fruits and vegetables (36), 4/ the lack of data, and the pioneering nature of the study precluded any sophisticated analysis. A rather mechanical approach had to be adopted for supply projection and an incomplete framework had to be used for demand projection. Supplies external to the 16 countries were assumed to maintain their present shares of EEC imports. Supply and de- mand projections for all 16 countries were based on up to 20 years historical data, and partial equilibrium analysis determined final price levels on an annual basis. Since EEC import prices were not available, CIF unit values had to be substituted. National wholesale price data were used to compile seasonal price indices for the 5 major EEC importing countries. These indices may be used to decompose projected annual prices (CIF unit values) into monthly components for use in project appraisal where seasonality is critical. It was recognized at the outset that a desk study would not allow for investigation of actual marketing practices in importing countries nor of the relative performance of various types of export organizations. Information in these areas is of importance in design of export-oriented projects, as in many cases improved marketing can greatly increase export earnings on the existing volumes, without waiting for additional production to be realized. Also, the return from such investment generally far exceeds that from increased production. To cover this aspect, a study was carried out on behalf of the Bank in the 5 major EEC importing countries by the consultant firm of Landell-Mills Associates, London, U.K., for use by Bank staff, member countries and other international agencies. That study incor- porates a comprehensive review of fruit and vegetable marketing in these countries, with emphasis on imports and an assessment of likely future developments in the marketing systems. It also includes a series of strategy studies to illustrate the use of the findings. 1/ Belgium-Luxembourg, France, Germany, Italy and the United Kingdom (actually six countries, but Belgium-Luxembourg are treated as a single unit). 2/ Cyprus, Egypt, Greece, Israel, Morocco, Spain and Turkey. 3/ In addition to the EEC-5 and the EMENA-7, the 16 countries include Denmark, Ireland and the Netherlands. 4/ See Appendix A for a complete listing of these.
 CHAPTER I STRUCTURE OF TRADE EEC Imports and EMENA-7 Exports 1.1 The individual components, (commodities and countries) subjected to detailed analysis were selected on the basis of their major contribution to EEC-EMENA trade in fruit and vegetables. The 36 commodities studied represent about 90% of the EMENA Region's fruit and vegetable exports. The seven EMENA Region developing countries (EMENA-7) selected for, detailed study account for about 90% of the fruit and vegetable exports of the Region's developing countries. The EEC countries (EEC-5) 1/ were selected on the basis of their major share of total net EEC fruit and vegetable imports (about 90%), and the EEC-5 also account for about 80% of the EMENA-7 fruit and vegetable exports. Of total EEC-5 fruit and vegetable imports, the EMENA-7 share is 27% and Other Regions is 45% (EEC's own share being 28%). It might appear that the EMENA-7 countries have.a minority market share, but "Other Regions" comprise 5 very distinct groups and about 150 individual countries, most of which have negligi- ble market shares. The major individual country exporters in this category, such as the US, South Africa and Australia, have concentrated on fruit exports to the EEC, such as apples and bananas, which, although major EEC imports, are insignificant as EMENA-7 exports, or such as citrus, in which they do not compete directly with EMENA-7 due to seasonal effects. Thus for the remaining commodities concerned, price projections are based on projections of net EEC aggregate import demand and export surpluses of the EMENA-7, and it is reason- able to assume that a constant EEC import market share is maintained by all countries in the Other Regions group. Structure of EEC-7/EMENA-7 Trade A. Regional Comparisons 1.2 The pattern of horticultural trade between the EEC-7 2/ and the EMENA-7 is a result of the fundamental economic and structural disparities between the two regions. The EMENA-7 region is economically poorer than the EEC-7. The combined EMENA-7 countries' GNP is about 10% of the EEC-7 coun- tries' total GNP. Although there are fewer people in the EMENA-7 region than in the EEC-7 region (137 million versus 249 million, respectively), the per capita GNP for the EEC-7 region is still three times larger than the per capita GNP of the EMENA-7 region. 1.3 As is typical of developing countries, agriculture plays a large role in the region, and most EMENA-7 exports to the EEC-7 are of a primary or agricultural nature. Almost half of the population of the EMENA-7 countries 1/ Belgium-Luxembourg, France, Germany, Italy, and the United Kingdom (actually six countries, but Belgium and Luxembourg are treated as a single unit). 2/ The six countries mentioned in footnote 1, plus the Netherlands.
 - 2 - resides in the agricultural sector, while less than 10% of the EEC-7 popula- tion resides in the agriculture sector. About 40% of the labor force in the EMENA-7 countries is employed in agriculture, compared with 10% in the EEC-7 countries. Thus, the agricultural sector accounts for 20% of GNP in the EMENA-7 countries and for only 5% of the GNP in the EEC-7 countries. Agri- cultural exports represent about 40% of the total value of EMENA-7 exports, while they account for only 6% of the value of EEC-7 exports. Agricultural exports are also less significant than agricultural imports of the EEC-7, since the latter account for 10% of the value of EEC-7 imports. 1.4 The greater wealth and smaller role of agriculture has made the EEC an attractive and traditional market for EMENA-7 exports. The commercial relationship between the two areas has been reinforced by complementary production and marketing seasons based on contrasting climates and soil. Geographic proximity and former colonial ties have enhanced the trade pattern. Statistics highlight the importance of this trade -- the EEC-7 region accounts for about 60% of the value of EMENA-7 total exports, and the EMENA-7 region accounts for about 12% of the value of EEC-7 imports. B. Role of EEC Horticulture in World Trade /1 ~~~~~~/2 /3 Table 1.1: EEC-9/- IMPORTS SHARE OF WORLD- HORTICULTURAL- IMPORTS (percentages - value based) 1970 1971 1972 1973 Fresh Fruit 53.5 55.3 55.9 56.1 Fresh Vegetables 59.3 59.8 59.5 60.0 Source: UN Yearbook of International Trade Statistics, 1974. /1 EEC-7, plus Denmark and Ireland. /2 World figures do not include Communist countries. 73 SITC classification numbers 051 and 053 are used as the basis for this definition. 1.5 The EEC is the single largest regional importer of fresh fruit and vegetables in the non-Communist world. As Table 1 indicates, the EEC's fresh fruit imports account for about 55% of world fruit imports and its fresh vege- table imports account for about 60% of world vegetable imports. Germany, UK and France are the largest world importers of both fresh fruit and vegetables in that order. The Netherlands and Belgium-Luxembourg rank seventh and ninth for fresh fruit and sixth and eighth as importers of fresh vegetables.
 Table 1.2: DISTRIBUTION OF WORLD IMPORTS BY SOURCE (percentages - value based) 1970 1971 1972 1973 Fresh Fruit EEC-9 18.6 20.8 22.0 21.0 EMENA-7 19.8 19.2 20.0 21.2 Rest of World 61.6 60.0 58.0 57.8 Fresh Vegetables EEC-9 36.1 35.9 37.8 38.2 EMENA-7 11.9 10.5 11.2 11.6 Rest of World 52.0 53.6 51.0 50.2 Sources: UN Yearbook of International Trade Statistics, 1974. 1.6 Despite its significance as an important world market, the EEC Region is also an important exporter of fresh fruit and vegetables. As Table 1.2 indicates, its exports account for about 20% of world fresh fruit imports, (with most exports going to other EEC countries and with some to centrally planned economy (CPE) countries) and 36% of world fresh vegetable imports. In comparison, EMENA-7 countries account for an equal share of world fresh fruit imports, but only 10% of world fresh vegetable imports. 1.7 Nature of EEC Horticultural Demand. The EEC supplies about 80% of EEC horticultural consumption through its own production and intra-EEC trade. EEC horticultural production has been constant in the 1970's; however, an aggregate picture conceals a contrasting trend between fresh fruit and fresh vegetable production. EEC fresh fruit production grew less than 10% between 1969 and 1975 and thus averaged less than 2% growth a year. Production actually fell between 1969 and 1972 and then increased in the following three years. In contrast, EEC fresh vegetable production fell 6% between 1970 and 1975, thus averaging about a 1% annual decline. Because of a drought, 1976 continued to be a bad year for EEC vegetable production, which fell by 22%, while EEC fruit production grew about 2% over the previous year. 1.8 EEC exports to other EEC countries have grown slowly, at an average annual rate of 1%. Most of the growth is attributed to intra-EEC vegetable trade which grew 18% between 1970 and 1973. Although EEC vegetable produc- tion has been declining, Dutch production, which supplies much of EEC consump- tion, has been growing so fast that the high growth of intra-EEC vegetable trade remains constant with the aggregate decline in EEC vegetable production. 1.9 Given the contrasting trends in EEC fruit and vegetable production and trade, the EEC supplies about 44% of its own fresh vegetable consumption and 85% of its own fresh fruit consumption by volume. EEC horticultural consumption patterns appear quite stable, growing at a consistent rate with GNP and population growth. Thus, there has been little or no change in per capita consumption in the last 10 years. On the average, EEC per capita consumption was about 244 kilograms of fresh fruit and vegetables per year.

 - 5 - 1.10 EEC consumption patterns are quite stable for most commodities and respond only to changes in price. Price changes for domestically produced items are moderated by the internal support price system 1/ and are rein- forced by restricted entry for imports from third countries. Thus there is limited opportunity to compete in domestic markets, even in those with a low self-sufficiency, but third country supply sources are plentiful so that com- petition remains keen and often success depends on improved marketing practices. 1.11 The EEC is relatively self-sufficient in horticultural commodities, but seasonal patterns of production, climatic constraints on the range of commodities which can be produced in the generally temperate conditions, and diverse tastes and preferences among member countries enhance the importance of horticultural imports from third countries in the EEC markets. In fact, on an annual basis, the EEC-7 is a net importer of most fresh fruit, vegetables and pulses. About two-thirds of the EEC horticultural imports originate in non-EEC or third countries. Germany (FR), France and the United Kingdom are the largest horticultural importers in that order, being net importers of fruit and pulses but not of vegetables, while Italy is a net importer of pulses but not of fruit and vegetables. 1.12 Table 1.3 presents the principal EEC-7 fruit, vegetable and pulse imports as reflected by their share of the value of imports and their share of total EEC-7 consumption. Fruits, by value, represent the most important EEC horticultural imports averaging 8% of EEC agricultural imports, compared with 3% for vegetables and 1% for pulses. Imports, including intra-EEC trade, represent an overwhelming share of most of the EEC fruit consumption and a significantly lower proportion of vegetables and pulses. A large share of imports (about 30%) are accounted for by intra-EEC trade. EMENA-7 countries account for over 50% of EEC citrus (orange, grapefruit and mandarin) consump- tion, 21% of EEC lentil consumption and 10 to 15% of EEC tomato, garlic and onion consumption.  - 6 - 1.13 Table 1.4 allows a comparison of the recent trends in the growth of EEC and world horticultural trade. The value of EEC horticultural imports has grown faster than that of world imports, especially for fruits. The substantial growth of EEC fruit imports is attributed to a modest growth in volume of imports (12%) and a greater growth in current prices due to Lnfla- tion. The growth of EEC fresh vegetable imports is roughly comparable to the trend in world vegetable imports. Similarly, the growth rates of EEC fresh fruit and vegetable imports have been roughly comparable. This is explained by the fact that while the volume of EEC fresh fruit imports increased and the volume of fresh vegetables declined, the prices of the fresh vegetables increased more than the prices of the fresh fruits, partly due to the short- ages in domestic EEC supplies. 1.14 EEC countries have promoted their vegetable exports to one another, attracted by the rapid growth in prices. But the performance of EMENA-7 fresh fruit and vegetable exports has also been good. EMENA-7 fresh fruit exports to the EEC have kept pace with growth of EEC import demand in volume and value terms while its volume of fresh vegetable exports has grown far faster than EEC imports, indicating a strong competitive position. Table 1.5: CHANGING SHARES OF EEC IMPORTS, BY SOURCE, 1970-73 Rest EEC EMENA-7 of World 1970 1978 1970 1978 1970 1978 …(percent - volume based)-------- Fresh Fruit 25 24 37 37 38 39 Fresh Vegetables 44 52 25 29 31 19 1.15 As Table 1.5 indicates, for fresh fruit imports there has been almost no change in the relative EEC, EMENA-7 and rest of world shares. This is consistent with the slow growth of EEC fresh fruit imports, based on rela- tively constant EEC supplies and per capita consumption. The trend is also consistent with the substantial lag between new plantings and the appearance of incremental production on stream, being reflected in relatively no change in pattern of trade (at least in the short run). Country gains are generally sought on the basis of better quality and improved marketing procedures in an effort to maintain market presence. 1.16 In contrast, there has been a marked shift in the EEC markel: shares of fresh vegetables to the benefit of the EEC sources of supply and to the detriment of other world sources. This shift is no doubt facilitated by the EEC's CAP system. The growth in the EMENA-7 share shows that it has remained competitive despite a reduction of EEC imports from third countries in the same period. C. Importance of Horticulture to EMENA-7 Countries 1.17 Each of the EMENA-7 countries is a net exporter of horticultural products, which comprise a significant share of the value of their agricul- tural and total exports. Specifically, fresh fruit, vegetables and pulses
 - 7 - range from 4 to 46% of the value of each country's total exports and 13 to 80% of the agricultural exports (Table 1.6). The principal EMENA-7 fruit exports are citrus (80% of the export value of fruit), grapes, melons, stonefruit (mostly peaches) and strawberries. D. Structure of EEC-7/EMENA-7 Horticultural Trade 1.19 Horticultural trade is significant for both EEC-7 and EMENA-7 coun- tries. The EEC-7 accounts for 82% of the value of EMENA-7 fruit, vegetable and pulse exports while the EMENA-7 countries account for about 30% of EEC-7 horticultural imports. A breakdown of the role of individual countries is provided in Table 1.8.
 - 8 - Table 1.8: SIGNIFICANCE OF EMENA-7 SOURCES OF EEC-7 IMPORTS EEC-7 MARKETS FOR EMENA-7 EXPORTS EMENA-7 Share of EEC-7 EEC-7 Share of EMENA-7 Horticultural Imports (%) Horticultural Exports (%) EMENA-7 Exporters EEC-7 Importers Spain 10 France 20 Morocco 8 Germany (FR) 23 Israel 4 United Kingdom 20 Greece 3 Netherlands 5 Cyprus 1.5 Belgium/Luxembourg 4 Turkey 1 Italy 2 Egypt 0O8 82 28 1.20 Although Germany (FR) is the largest EEC-7 importer of horticultural products, it ranks second only to France as the leading EEC market for FMENA-7 horticultural exports. Spain and Morocco are easily the leading EMENA-7 horticultural exporterso Spain's dominance is attributed to its well-developed horticultural subsector, extensive and efficient marketing and distribution linkage with all EEC markets, and its close geographic proximity. It is the leader without possessing the sizable tariff concessions that are so impor- tant to the other EMENA-7 countries. Morocco's position, in contrast, is the result of historical trading ties with France, which alone accounts for 56% of the value of Morocco fruit, vegetable and pulse exports. Although Morocco has substantial tariff concessions applicable to all EEC markets, its trade is still concentrated in the French marketo Bad weather caused a fall in Moroccan exports in 1975 and 1976, but there has also been a noticeable shift from exports to the EEC to the USSR. Shifts to export varieties favored by the EEC has been slower than expected and is attributed partially to inadequate price incentives. Israel, a relatively new exporter, has achieved considerable success as an exporter by expanding its fruit and vegetable marketing strategy with focus on selected key commodities (grape- fruit, avocado, strawberries, shamouti and oval oranges) for which there is considerably less competition (EEC or EMENA-7)0 The Israeli success has been reinforced through substantial tariff concessions on these same commodities granted through the 1975 EEC/Israel bilateral agreemento Although Greece has had duty-free entry for most of its horticultural products, its EEC trade is primarily concentrated in the German market and its key exports (cucumbers and peaches) still represent only a small share of the value of German imports. The high level of fruit and vegetable consumption in Greece, with a substan- tial proportion of its production allocated to processing, may constrain available export supplies, but Greece is still eager to expand its fresh horticultural exports to the EEC, particularly as part of its preparation for ultimate entry into the EEC. On the other hand, Greece does not seem to have a comparative economic advantage vis-a-vis other EMENA-7 countries for most horticultural commodities, and entry into EEC may lead to production cost increases which will-only hinder further its competitive position unless they
 - 9 - are offset by substantial investment in improved production and marketing systems. Cyprus's position among EMENA-7 exporting countries has been attributed to its traditional ties with the UK, which accounts for 20Z of Cyprus's fruit and vegetable exports. However, since the political problems in 1973, its exports to the EEC-7 have fallen considerably despite the concurrent signing of an EEC-9/Cyprus agreement which in essence guaranteed Cyprus's share of the UK market. 1.21 Turkey's relatively weak position as an exporter to the EEC has recently been due to stalemated negotiations with the EEC. It is complicated by the political dispute with Greece and an overall trade deficit with the EEC. Turkey has exported a relatively small volume of potatoes, oranges, lemons and dry pulses to the EEC-7, but other EMENA-7 countries possess more favorable tariff concessions which Turkey now wants extended to it as well. 1.22 Finally, Egypt's exports to the EEC-7 are concentrated among onions, oranges and dry beans, and Egypt possesses a'significant share of only one EEC market. CHAPTER II EEC POLICIES AND AGREEMENTS REGULATING TRADE WITH EMENA-7 COUNTRIES A. Introduction 2.1 Trade between the EEC as a customs union and the Mediterranean third countries (non-EEC members) is governed by three different policies: (1) Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) 1/ (2) Bilateral Agreements with a) EMENA-7 countries and b) other third countries (3) Broader Mediterranean Policy This chapter describes each of the three policies and their implications for EMENA-7 fruit, vegetable and pulse shares of EEC markets. 2.2 The Common Agricultural Policy is an elaborate price regulating and tariff setting mechanism which supports and protects the EEC agricultural sector. 2/ Initiated in 1962, the regime governs the stabilization and 1/ Covers all main commodities except lamb, wool and potatoes. The Commis- sion is preparing new regulations to bring potatoes into the CAP by 1978. 2/ See Appendix 1 for a functional description of the CAP mechanism.
 - 10 - protection of 96% of EEC-6 agricultural production and trade0 Upon joining the EEC in 1973, Denmark, Ireland and the United Kingdom agreed to begin implementing the CAP immediately and to adjust price levels and customs charges to equal those of the EEC-6 common levels over a five-year period to end in 1978. The CAP now affects over 70% of the agricultural production and trade of the three new members. 2.3 The EEC market support and protection system (CAP) for fruits and vegetables is effective in protecting EEC production and trade from competi- tion by third country imports during principal marketing periods. The two basic components - an internal market stabilization system and an import market regulation system - operate on a price regulating basis. 2.4 The internal market stabilization system indirectly affects EEC imports from third countries. The principal aim of the system is the pre- vention of market fluctuations in order to encourage relatively high levels of EEC supplies. However, a large volume of EEC supplies, accounting for a large share of EEC consumption, serves to restrict the demand for imports from third countries. At the same time, the relatively high prices in the EEC markets attract greater imports from third countries as exporters try to maximize their return. 2.5 The CAP import market regulation scheme directly affects imports from third countries in order to protect further the EEC supplies. The imposition of a common customs tariff (CCT) and its variation by season keeps imports from third countries out of the EEC markets during peak EEC produc- tion and marketing periods. Additional protection for selected sensitive commodities 1/ is sought through the imposition of a reference price system. The reference price serves as a minimum import price. When imports enter at prices which are below the reference price a countervailing charge is then assessed to insure that the import prices remain competitive with domestic prices of the higher cost EEC produce. The combined effect of these elements is to constrain the demand for imports from third countries (and thus the market size) by limiting their access to the EEC markets and by reducing the exporters' return as compared with free trade levels. B. Effectiveness of CAP 2.6 The CAP, ten years after its inception, has not been fully applied to fruits and vegetables because of the special nature of these commodities. The EEC is not self-sufficient in fruits or vegetables because of the season- ality of production, impossibility of growing certain crops profitably within the EEC in view of high labor and fuel costs, and the difficult administrative and transport problems which arise because of the perishability of the produce. Thus, the EEC is more dependent on fresh horticultural imports from third 1/ References are applied on a seasonal basis to apples, cherries, cucumbers, grapes, lemons, mandarins, peaches, pears, plums, oranges and tomatoes.
 - 11 - countries than for other agricultural commodities. Third countries account for two-thirds of EEC horticultural imports. Even in the main fruit and vegetable producing countries, profitable access is possible during seasonal gaps in the market or during shortages caused by bad weather. On occasion (admittedly rare), a relaxing of restrictions throughout the EEC permits it to supplement its internal supplies. The suspension of import duties on a wide range of vegetables in the autumn/winter of 1976-1977 is an example of this flexibility. 2.7 There are inherent conflicts in interest between EEC producers, consumers, importers and third country exporters which the EEC regulations have not fully reconciled. EEC producers feel that there is insufficient market protection in the fruit and vegetable sector relative to other com- modities. Wishing to sell all they can produce at prices which insure profit and income levels consistent with labor in other sectors, they press for higher reference prices and the extension of them to other horticultural commodities in order to restrict the amount of third country competition. On the other hand, consumers feel that the EEC is subsidizing the producers not only through the market stabilization and import schemes but also through the farmer income support policies. They desire sufficiently large volumes of produce to insure that prices are reasonably low, and they are actively seeking lower reference prices and stricter surveillance of quality, espe- cially of EEC produce, in order that the market size can be expanded and that there will be a downward pressure on prices. Importers, of course, want the market expanded to increase the volume of produce handled, so they want lower reference prices and lower tariff barriers. 2.8 Third country exporters have a variety of concerns. For many commodities, the structure of the CAP confines imports from third countries to the EEC off-season and thus reduces their potential exports as compared to free trade levels. Competition among third countries in the off-season becomes intense, given similar production and marketing export seasons. Be- cause these commodities are generally price inelastic, even a small increase in the aggregate volume of imports from third countries can lead to a much larger decline in prices; this then offsets the return to exporters and may even close the market to the more marginal suppliers. 2.9 Because the CAP system has not been very successful in preventing market instability, despite the complex price regulating mechanism, volatile price fluctuations make it difficult for EMENA-7 and other third countries to plan on a guaranteed flow of produce to the EEC on a regulated basis. The CAP also serves as a disincentive for increased investment in the horticultural subsectors within the EMENA-7 countries if the output is to be directed to the EEC markets. 2.10 Other problems arise in the implementation of the CAP. The quantity of EEC production relates very closely to the level of the reference price, which is usually higher than the market price. This encourages higher EEC production levels in anticipation of greater profits. Frequently, it also leads to oversupply and to poor quality, as well as to market intervention for maintenance of the market price. The disposal of produce acquired in this way
 - 12 - is a significant problem. In cases of oversupply, imports from third coun- tries may be completely cut off, with resulting uncertainty for the exporting countries. Export subsidies may be paid, equal to the difference between EEC and world market prices0 During periods of oversupply, subsidies are neces- sary to enable EEC producers to compete in the lower-priced free market. In cases of shortage, the EEC trade restrictions can be suspended to encourage greater third country supplies. Maintaining a proper market balance becomes a very delicate operation at which the EEC has not been very successful, but it is in almost everyone's interest - exporters and importers alike - to continue to aim for the achievement of that goal. 2.11 Applying common CAP regulations to diverse market situations also creates problems for third country exporters. For example, when import prices fall below the reference prices on a main EEC market, countervailing charges are assessed on imports of that commodity in all the EEC markets, placing imports at a distinct disadvantage in markets where the entry price was already higher than the reference price. However, in other instances, individua.L national interpretation of EEC regulations, intra-EEC variations in market behavior and diverse seasons and tastes among EEC member countries do result in different applications of the EEC regime, at least at the market leve.L. The difference in interpretation of EEC import restrictions between Germany (FR) at-one extreme and France and Italy at the other means a considerabLe difference in ease of access and profitability. Substantial variations exist, for example, in the application of quality standards. 2.12 The EEC has granted preferential treatment for imports from third countries through the negotiation of two types of special bilateral agreements - association and preferential. These agreements generally provide for the reciprocal elimination or reduction of customs duties on some or all indius- trial and agricultural foods. In the case of association agreements, the EEC also extends financial and technical aid, which can often be more signifLcant than the tariff concessions themselves. Currently, the EEC has such agreements with many countries in Western and Eastern Europe, in the Mediterranean region, in Africa, and in Latin America. Each of the EMENA-7 countries now has a bilateral agreement with the EEC. After 1973, new bilateral agreements were concluded with Cyprus, Morocco and Israel, and negotiations have been underway with Spain and Turkey so that full coverage of the CAP, including the tariff preferences, can be applied to the full EEC membership. 2.13 EMENA-7 countries, given their location and low wage structure, have traditionally been in a position to capture a significant share of EEC fruit and vegetable markets. Tariff concessions granted in bilateral agreements and historical trade patterns from colonial associations have aided EMENA-7 to the point where, between 1970 and 1973, they provided almost 30% of EEC fruit and vegetable imports; a roughly equal share to that of EEC sources. To date the tariff concessions in the agreement have been of marginal benefit to the third countries which possess them. In periods of oversupply, the concessions can be suspended. In periods of undersupply, there is ample room for countries with and without concessions to enter the market so that benefits to the third country supplier which has the concession are marginal. The proliferation of such concessions among a wider range of commodities and
 - 13 - to a broader group of countries has further weakened the benefit to any single country. The tariff concessions, however, do enable third countries which possess them to retain part of the levy that generally goes to EEC producers and exporters through the farm income and export subsidy programs of the CAP. 2.14 A Broader Mediterranean Policy is a more recent ideal directed toward the harmonization of EEC policies and tariff concessions with respect to Mediterranean third countries in order to equalize the competitive trade positions (not trade concessions) among the Mediterranean partners. The policy aims to reduce imbalances emanating from weaknesses in both the CAP and bilateral agreements. As part of this policy, the EEC has negotiated the 1973 and 1977 Egyptian accord with a broader view of its competitive position vis-a-vis other Mediterranean countries. The EEC has also granted improved tariff concessions to Israel and Morocco to bring their competitive position in line with Spain, the leading EMENA-7 fruit and vegetable exporter to the EEC even without major tariff concessions. EEC/Turkey negotiations have been stalemated for over a year as Turkey attempts to improve its status vis-a-vis other Mediterranean suppliers, mainly Greece and Cyprus. 2.15 A major threat to a broader approach is the current consideration of the entry of Greece, Spain and Portugal into the EEC. The talks are already plagued with Greece's opposition to combining the entry question of all three countries into one negotiation package. Their eventual entry into the EEC will call for further assessment of the broader Mediterranean objec- tives if other EMENA-7 third countries are not to be forced out of EEC markets by the overwhelming competition from within the larger EEC. Earlier focus on these problems may have enabled the EEC to postpone consideration of the more difficult entry question at least another decade. However, it is suggested here that the EEC focus on balancing Mediterranean interests may have come too late, arising just at the time some third countries are demanding more preferences, including full entry into the EEC. C. Other Geographic Competition of EMENA-7 Countries in EEC-7 Markets 2.16 Competition among third countries has heightened in the traditional EEC markets. Up to now the proliferation of bilateral agreements both in the Mediterranean region and throughout the world has led to a mad scramble by third countries to obtain preferential treatment and, in some cases, financial aid in order to gain access to the coveted EEC markets. Thus, the relative -weakness of the CAP has been exacerbated by increasing pressure from external forces. Developed third countries have opposed the special treatment of developing third countries, and both groups are important to the EEC for economic and political reasons. Besides, the inherent narrowness of granting preferences on a bilateral basis has created a situation in which no one ever feels satisfied because of the dynamic environment in which all this takes place. Just as one country obtains a tariff reduction, a similar or better reduction is given to another country, often a competitor, and the initial benefit is reduced. It becomes unclear whether the moves then lead to increased trade liberalization or the need to impose further protective or restrictive policies.
 - 14 - 2.17 Ten years ago the EMENA-7 region was the undisputed leader among third countries in supplying the EEC markets with fruit, vegetables and pulses0 Such is not the case today. Southern hemisphere countries, some of which are Commonwealth countries (especially South Africa, Australia and New Zealand), have garnered the major share of all the EEC horticultural import markets, not just that of the United Kingdom. Eastern European countries have expanded their share of EEC markets for selected fruit ancl vegetables despite the imposition of quotas on imports from this region. ACP countries are increasing their investment in the relatively high valued horticultural commodities with a view to exporting to the EEC0 They also have substantial tariff concessions, including duty-free entry for much of their horticultural exports to EEC, and they are not subject to the EEC reference price system. These advantages partially offset their higher transport costs. Mexico not only now exports to the United States but to the EEC as well, and Cuba's likely improved ties with the West may lead t.o its regaining a significant share of this horticultural trade0 2.18 The implications for this heightened intensity of competition for EMENA-7 supplies is that substantial investments and improvements such as the provision of storage to lengthen seasonal advantages and improve quality of produce, resort to cost-effective technology that does not displace labor, and research on new varieties will all be required just for EMENA-7 count.ries to continue to maintain, much less improve, their volume of exports to the EEC and to keep their EEC market shares0 2.19 Effect of Policies and Agreements on Third Country Imports by Commodity. The EEC policies and agreements have a diverse impact on imports of horticultural commodities from third countries, including those from EMENA-7 countries. The EEC policies do protect the majority of the EEC f'ruit, vegetables and pulse imports from third country competition. The barriers (relatively high tariffs, granting of few concessions, and in some instances imposition of the reference price system throughout the year) are most effective for apples, pears, plums, grapes, eggplants, carrots, cauliflowers, celery and lettuce because there is sizable production and intra-EEC trade to protect. With the exception of a few of these items, where one or two EMENA-7 countries have been given substantial tariff concessions, EMENA-7 countri.es are pretty much locked out of EEC markets for these commodities. 2.20 Off-season demand for imports from third countries is substantial for cherries, peaches, strawberries, asparagus, artichokes, cucumbers, new potatoes and tomatoes. This is aided by lower tariffs in the off-season, higher intra-EEC and reference prices with which to compete (because intra-EEC supply is lower in this period), and strong seasonal EEC demand. EMENA-7 countries account for a major share of EEC imports of these commodities f'rom third countries. 2.21 There is relatively little EEC production, or intra-EEC trade, for oranges, green peppers, avocadoes, mandarins and clementines, bananas, grapefruit and melons, so there is relatively little need for EEC policies to protect EEC suppliers. However, tariff concessions to EMENA-7 countries have enabled them to maintain large shares of EEC import markets for avocadoes,
 - 15 - mandarins and tangerines, oranges, green peppers, grapefruit and melon. The imposition of reference price system on oranges protects EMENA-7 supplies from lower-priced Eastern European exports to the EEC. Tariff concessions to ACP countries and the freedom from imposition of reference prices enables ACP countries to provide formidable competition to EMENA-7 suppliers for sweet peppers, green beans and dry pulses. Preferences for ACP banana exports to the EEC virtually exclude EMENA-7 supplies. The EEC regime has a weaker impact as other factors impede third country exports to the EEC. Such appears to be the case for apricots (weak demand) and for cabbage and green peas (high transport costs). As third countries overcome these other barriers and impediments, the effects of the EEC policies and concessions are likely to be more significant.

 - 19 - CHAPTER III SEASONALITY OF TRADE 3.1 This chapter examines the EEC import seasons 1/ in relation to the principal EMENA-7 export seasons by looking at historical seasonal EEC import trade patterns of eleven 2/ selected commodities. The effects of the CAP (Chapter II) reference prices and third country competition on this trade pattern are also discussed. Future prospects for seasonally based EMENA-7 exports to the EEC are then concluded. Prospects for EMENIA-7 exports are most favorable (optimal) during the EEC import season yielding the highest unit return (highest prices exclusive of tariffs). EEC import volumes in each season are compared to determine the market potential for the EMENA-7 region. It is noteworthy that the optimal seasons are not necessarily identical to the peak EEC import seasons. Peak third country imports generally occur during the EEC off-production season, as the large volume of intra-EEC trade aligns major EEC import seasons with major production seasons in the EEC. The optimal seasons are contrasted with EMENA-7's past market shares to determine when exports might possibly be expanded. Seasonality of EEC Imports 3.2 Throughout the year, the EEC is a net importer of the eleven commod- ities. However, EEC shares of EEC imports show large seasonal variations. In the peak EEC production seasons, the EEC supplies up to 99% of its import needs, except for oranges (5%). In the off production seasons, the EEC share of imports is substantially lower, averaging only 45% of the imports in the peak production seasons. The import volume in each season varies, so the scope for third country imports is not perfectly correlated with decreased intra-EEC market shares. As seen in Chapter II, the CAP is designed primarily to protect returns of domestic producers by reducing, generally to the point of almost total exclusion, imports from third countries during the EEC peak production seasons, with tariffs either imposed or increased on appropriate commodities. Thus the peak EEC production season is also the peak market volume period and the season of lowest market price. The CAP import restric- tions in the EEC peak production (low price) seasons have had negative effects ,on export earnings of EMENA-7 countries. Third country exports are unable to realize the full market potential in the lucrative EEC markets, as their margins are greatly reduced by the common customs tariff (CCT). 3/ 3.3 The combined effects of peak EEC production and the CAP serve to make the EEC off production season the peak season for imports from third countries. 1/ Available trade data is divided into semi-annual seasons; Table 3.1 lists the import seasons. 2/ Apples, grapes, oranges, pears, strawberries, cucumbers, lettuce (cabbage), potatoes (new), tomatoes, fresh beans, fresh peas. 3/ See Table 3.2 for CCT rates on a seasonal basis.

Table 3.4: SEASONAL BASES FOR REFERENCE PRICES Commodity Season Apples Jan 1 - Dec 31 Grapes, Table July 15 - Oct 31 Oranges Dec 1 - Apr 30 Pears Jan 1 - Dec 31 Cucumbers Feb 1 - Nov 30 Tomatoes Apr 1 - Dec 31 Conclusions The EMENA-7 region has gained its current dominant position for most items largely by virtue of past colonial ties, its geographic position and excellent climatic conditions. Historically, the EMENA-7 countries have concentrated the volume of their exports to the EEC in the higher priced seasons (Table 3.6: EMENA-7 shares on a seasonal basis). Exceptions to this are apples, grapes, oranges and pears. For each of these commodities, increased export earnings are possible, if production/export seasons can be shifted to the higher priced seasons. Tables 3.7 and 3.8 summarize histori- cal EMENA-7 performance and the most favorable seasons in the EEC markets. In general, however, the EMENA-7 performance has concentrated on the favorable seasons and thus leaves little further room for overall improvement in seasonal exports except for apples, grapes, oranges, pears; whether production can be shifted for these commodities needs to be determined. As labor rates increase and water supplies do not, the EMENA-7 region will face stiffer competition in the world market. The EEC has increasingly granted concessions to the developing world, notably the ACP countries, and will increase imports from other regions at the expense of the EMENA-7 countries.

 - 30 - CHAPTER IV PRICE PROJECTIONS 4.1 The price projections emerging from this study summarize the market outlook in the EEC for the 36 fruits and vegetables studied. These are based on supply and demand forecasts through 1985. 1/ The aim of the review pre- sented in this chapter is to point out the prospects of future EMENA-7 exports to the EEC on the basis of the projections. These projections should be con- sidered as anticipated trends in prices, rather than actual price levels. Methodological Considerations 4.2 The study contains numerous methodological and data weaknesses which should be appreciated before the results are applied. There was a signif-icant lack of EEC and EMENA data, thus requiring use of UN-FAO figures in cases where individual country statistics were lacking, with the result that there are internal inconsistencies in some of the data. 4.3 The method used for projecting production is a mechanical extrapola- tion of past trends, including their cyclical patterns, which are influenced by a wide range of regular and irregular events. However, although weak in explanatory ability, it is extremely good in reproducing past patterns of supply. To compensate for the economic shortcoming in the methodology, a con- sulting firm, Landell-Mills Associates (LMA), was commissioned to check the projections (supply and demand) with market specialists in Europe and wit:h economic studies available there. For the most part, the consultant work substantiated the projections of the study. 4.4 The income and price elasticities used in demand estimation are unrelated to each other since they were estimated in separate studies which used different methods. They are also probably out of date, having been esti- mated on a data base of 1955-65. No cross price elasticities were available to judge the substitution effects among related commodities. An exhaustiLve search for better estimates was made both by ourselves and.the consultant, but to no avail. 4.5 All of the projections were made with the assumption of a statiLc environment which may not be relevant in a dynamic future. For example, it is assumed that there will be no basic changes in the general structure of trade within the EEC and among the EEC-7, EMENA-7 and other regions during the projected time period. Many other factors, external to the model, such as changes in governmental policies, could alter the projections substan- tially, as also could structural changes, such as the entry of Greece and Spain to the EEC. Nonetheless, since the supply projections are based on a long period which has involved such phenomena and still have a high 1/ See Appendix A for a review of methodology used to make these projec- tions.
 - 31 - explanatory value and since in many cases, even with annual crops, a fairly regular cyclical supply pattern is observed and modelled, the supply extrapola- tions cannot be ignored. The results add up to a market outlook statement incomparably better than anything which might be attempted in the context of an individual project appraisal or a sector paper and also far more prag- matic and reliable than a ubiquitous, but costly, consultant firm's eyeball assessment of overall market prospects. Improvement on this analysis will necessitate a much greater data collection effort than the substantial volume assembled, requiring estimation of supply and demand functions for all com- modities and all countries of concern. 4.6 Use of the projections should take into account the fact that, although the projections for the EEC have been economically verified in the consultant study, the projections for the EMENA-7 countries have not. Much of this verification work can be included in the sector and project appraisal stage for the selected EMENA countries. The non-availability of specific EMENA country data (i.e., production costs and seasons, governmental price and fiscal policy, marketing and transport information, and information on physical technical constraints on production, etc.) prohibited any intensive analysis of comparative costs, which is a fundamental aspect of any attempt to ascertain the international competitive positions of the EMENA-7 countries. EEC Market Outlook 4.7 The market outlook, as summarized by expected price fluctuations, is deceiving. In constant terms there are few projected price increases, but with the projected inflation rates all but two commodities have price increases in current terms for the period 1974 to 1985. The principal conclusion to be drawn from our price analysis is that in constant terms the EEC market outlook for fresh horticultural imports will, in regard to most commodities, continue to deteriorate further through 1985. These projections indicate general trends, and not actual import prices in any given year. The significance of the overall trend, rather than precision in estimating actual prices and annual volume is greater in medium term investment strategy in EMENA-7 countries, for this is the proper basis for project design and plan- ning. 4.8 Table 4.1 summarizes the constant price projections by commodity. The commodities are grouped, by percentage constant price changes in constant US dollar terms, from greatest price increases to greatest price declines. The characteristics of each group and the consequences for the EMENA-7 region are discussed below. Significant constant price increases (greater than 1% per year in constant dollar terms) are projected for six commodities (melons, peaches, onions, potatoes, lentils, and dry peas). These all have substan- tial EEC import market shares and are of relatively low unit value; the EMENA-7 countries have the largest share (averaging 68% by volume). For all but peaches, EMqENA-7 exports to the EEC are projected to decline between 1976 and 1985, while the EEC net imports are projected to increase for all except lentils, imports of which remain constant. When these constant price increases are adjusted for inflation, there are large current dollar price increases (greater than 10% per year). The apparently large price rises will help to

 - 33 - increase exports both from the EMENA-7 countries and the rest of the world. Greater competition, combined with the trend of declining EMENA-7 production and exports, will make it difficult for the EMENA-7 countries to maintain their current majority share position. 4.9 Most of the commodities have very small projected constant price movements of less than 1% per year plus or minus. Those with price increases (cherries, lemons, oranges, strawberries, lettuce, and fresh beans) are of higher unit value, and EEC net imports are expected to rise. Historically, EMENA-7 countries have had 50% of the EEC import markets for these six commod- ities. Declines are projected in EMENA-7 exports for cherries and lettuce, but moderate increases are foreseen for the other items. However, growth of EMENA-7 exports is seen to be much lower than the growth of EEC import demand. 4.10 Commodities with small constant price declines (pears, plums,, artichokes, cauliflower, celery, eggplant, garlic, tomatoes and fresh peas) are of average unit values, and the EMENA-7 share of EEC imports is rela- tively low at only 44%. For plums, artichokes and tomatoes, EEC imports are projected to decline, with plums becoming a net export item; EMENA-7 exports are expected to increase for artichokes, celery, garlic and fresh peas, and decline for pears, plums, and tomatoes. 4.11 Significant constant price declines (greater than 1% per year) are projected for apples, apricots, avocadoes, grapefruit, mandarins-tangarines, asparagus, carrots, cucumbers, green peppers, broad beans, and dry beans. EMENA-7's exports to the EEC are projected to increase for all of these com- modities, often much faster than EEC import demand. EMENA-7 shares of this category average about 45%. Current dollar price declines are expected for broad beans and dry peas in spite of projected inflation of greater than 10% per year on average. The outlook for EMENA-7 exports is one of decreasing returns, as current prices are not expected to keep up with inflation. 4.12 Price projections were not computed for bananas, cabbage and spinach because of the EMENA-7 countries' insignificant share of EEC imports of these items. Other regions are projected to supply 100% of the EEC's imports of these commodities. For all three commodities, projected EEC import demand increases substantially, indicating possible constant dollar price increases. Table grape prices also were not projected because the data included wine grape data in an inseparable fashion. 4.13 The price projections, under the assumption of constant share trade patterns, reflect the general trend toward oversupply in the EEC import markets. For the commodities with constant dollar price increases in the long run, there are considerable fluctuations from year to year, thus making it very difficult to achieve a profitable production and marketing system. Unless the EMENA-7 suppliers are able to adjust to these frequent market fl'ictuations, which EEC trade policies tend to magnify, they will be unable to take advantage of any favorable EEC trade prospects. 4.14 For many of the 36 commodities, even those projected to have small price declines, opportunities for profits often exist only in certain
 - 34 - seasons0 1/ Care must be taken not to flood EEC markets with the 36 commodi- ties in any one period, or there would be substantially lower returns to all suppliers. External Factors 4.15 Because of the possible entry of Greece and Spain into the E1C, their position should be contrasted with that of other EMENA-7 suppliers. Spain is the foremost supplier of fresh fruit and vegetables to the EECo Currently, Greece enjoys duty-free entry privileges for its exports to the EEC but is subject to the reference price systemo If Spain and Greece enter the EEC, it is likely that they will be in the best position to take advantage of the limited favorable prospects and will leave little, if any, room for expansion for the remaining EMENA-5 suppliers. Their entry would shifl the EEC trade balance from a net importer to a net exporter of fruits and vege- tables on an annual basis0 4.16 EEC trade concessions 2/ to third countries other than the EM4ENA-7 will undoubtedly increase their competitiveness for EEC imports and wi:Ll put great pressure on the EMENA-7 suppliers to maintain their current market shares. EMENA-7's Future Strategy 4.17 If the EMENA-7 countries (and particularly the 5 which would remain outside an enlarged EEC-12) wish to maintain their current shares of E]EC horticultural imports, steps must be taken toward more cost-efficient pro- duction and marketing systems rather than increased production efforts. This is of greater significance in view of the minimal price increases for very few of the commodities, and by declines of constant prices for the remaining commodities0 Cost efficiencies will have a much greater effect on profits by 1985 than major shifts in production0 4.18 Specific plans and methods of investment for implementing greater efficiency in production in the EMENA-7 region are beyond the scope of this study0 But certain general areas for study are worth recommending0 The quality of EMENA-7 produce in the EEC markets should be improved through better packaging, handling and storageo This would ensure the highest prices available for the produce exported0 The marketing system could be resl:ruc- tured efficiently through a coordinated system of EEC market intelligence, to plan exports to the most profitable markets through improved distribution networks from farms to EEC consumption. 1/ See Chapter 3: Seasonality of Trade, and the monthly price indices, Annex A, Table 8. 2/ See Chapter 2.
 35 - APPENDIX A METHODOLOGY A major part of this study consisted of projections of supply and demand for the 36 commodities covered with respect to each of the EEC-9 and EMENA-7 countries. The supply (production) projections were based on a time series of 15-20 years (usually 1955-1973). To this series a regression line was fitted and then projected using the historical cyclical trend line until 1985. The basic formula was as follows: Q = a + b + Sin (et) + c cos (6t) where: Q = production a, b, c - are regression coefficients as computed e = critical angle (cycle) t = number of years (from beginning of production data until 1985) The critical angle was derived from past cyclical trends and then used in the regression algorithm to compute the coefficients that gave the best fit. In most cases these methods resulted in substantially bette5 esti- mates than simple linear regression, as was indicated by a very high R at above the 95% significance level. This method is purely mechanical and is based on the assumption that past trends and cycles will continue into the future. On the demand (consumption) side, it was assumed that consumption is a linear function of population and GNP, using the following formula: [C/POP] x YG x r x POP + 1 = C + I where: C = apparent consumption in year 1 POP Population in year I YG Growth rate of per capita income (GNP) per annum 4X = inc.ome elasticity of demand POP + 1 = Population in year t + 1 C + 1 = Projected consumption in year t + 1 Apparent consumption (production less the net trade balance) in 1974 was used as the starting point for the projections. Net trade balances, indicating surplus supply or demand, were derived from the projections. For the EEC, these were summed to determine the pro- jected net import demand for each commodity. For the EMENA-7 countries, we looked at potential export supply and then used historical percentages of exports going to the EEC to estimate future supplies available for sale in the EEC markets. Other region's supplies to the EEC were not projected but were assumed to remain at a constant percentage (average for 1973 and 1974) of EEC import demand. These supply levels were then used to determine the years in which net excess supply or demand occurred. 1/ This excess supply/demand can 1/ See Annex A, Table 5: Projected Market Outlook Summary.
 - 36 - APPENDIX A be considered as a market imbalance, which can only be corrected by a shift in prices. Our price projections are based on these market imbalance figures and determined in partial equilibrium analysis by the price shift necessary to ensure market clearance. Price elasticities of demand were used to estimate market clearing price shifts. These have been estimated for only a few horticultural commodi- ties or commodity groups. Estimates from a variety of sources were used as a guideline for setting the range in which all the commodities would be placed0 However, the commodities were also ranked in terms of their unit values in order to provide some judgmental input as to a generally acceptable elasticity estimate for each commodity0 Actual estimated elasticities were modified by means of such judgmental input, prior to using them0 The ranking is consistent with economic theory, i.e., the price elasticity of most goods is higher, (i) the more the good is regarded as a luxury, (ii) the greater the number of substitutes, (iii) the larger the item in the budget, and (iv) the longer the period of analysis. Also demand tends to be more elastic at higher than at lower prices. Exceptions were also noted for a selected group of commodities (artichokes, avocadoes and garlic, to name a few) which are still consumed in such small quantities that they may be more price inelastic than their relative unit values would suggest. Price elasticities of demand ranged from El high of 2.07 to a low of 0.5. Base prices were CIF unit values as calculated from country trade statistics for 1974 because there were no data available on actual import (CIF) prices. Unit values were obtained for each country and all 36 commodi- ties. Since these are annual import prices, they are applicable to imports from third countries. The following tables contain the elasticities (price and income), population and GNP real growth rates used.

doc.repnme: Fruit and vegetable exports from the Mediterranean area to the EEC
doc.abstracts: The paper reviews trade patterns and volumes of the major fruit and vegetable exporters among developing Mediterranean countries and the major EEC importing countries, with due consideration of seasonality of production. By setting the array of EEC import market regulations against the seasonality of the EEC domestic production and the EEC's Common Agricultural Policy, some implications for future trade prospects are developed. Finally, with this background, projections through 1985 of domestic supply and demand for 36 different fruits and vegetables are made, and from these trade and international prices are then projected.
